item.title: Uber to pay drivers a minimum wage, holiday pay and pensions
item.description: It comes after a court ruling on driver status and could have consequences across the gig economy.

item.title: Atlanta shootings: Asian women among eight killed at three spas
item.description: The attacks around Atlanta, Georgia, come amid a surge in hate crime directed at Asian-Americans.

item.title: Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid jab safe, insists Hancock
item.description: People should "get the jab", the health secretary says, after some countries suspend its use.

item.title: Syria: The scars left by a school bombing
item.description: BBC cameraman Darren Conway has returned to Syria to meet survivors of the Iqra school bombing, the aftermath of which he filmed in 2013.

item.title: Crime: Thieves, robbers and burglars to be fitted with GPS tags
item.description: Police will be able to cross-reference data with crime reports to see if offenders were in the area.

item.title: Regent honeyeater: Endangered bird 'has forgotten its song'
item.description: The natural song of the regent honeyeater has essentially "disappeared" in 12% of the population.

item.title: Russia's Putin authorised pro-Trump 'influence' campaign, US intelligence says
item.description: A US intelligence report alleges Russia's president approved efforts to influence the 2020 election.

item.title: Refund plan for energy bills when direct debits are too high
item.description: Energy regulator Ofgem says customers' overpayments are being used to pay for "unsustainable business".

item.title: Coronavirus exposed 'much larger' rough sleeping issue, says committee
item.description: MPs praise the government's Everyone In scheme, but say it "exposed the scale of the task" at hand.

item.title: Covid: Catch-up tuition not helping poorest pupils, says NAO
item.description: Fewer than half of pupils who have received tuition are among poorest, says National Audit Office.

item.title: Democracy is in retreat, warns Dominic Raab
item.description: Dominic Raab will argue the UK should use its "clout" to be "a force for good in the world".

item.title: Salmond complaints were 'encouraged', claims Tory MP
item.description: Former minister David Davis uses parliamentary privilege to make the allegation during a House of Commons debate.

item.title: 'More divisive than Brexit' - The battle over LTNs
item.description: The schemes were introduced to tackle increasing traffic on minor roads but some face fierce opposition.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: PM attacked on China and Duke leaves hospital
item.description: Prince Philip features on several front pages, as does criticism of Boris Johnson's "soft" line on China.

item.title: What we wish we'd known about infertility
item.description: In the US, one in eight couples experience infertility. But a culture of silence and stigma means most people suffer alone.

item.title: 'The Gospel Truth?' Covid-19 vaccines and the danger of religious misinformation
item.description: Many religious leaders are spreading the word that vaccines are safe and effective, but some are undermining that message.

item.title: Cladding crisis: 'Repairs could cost more than our flat is worth'
item.description: A couple paying for cladding replacement say the costs could leave them bankrupt or with crippling loans.

item.title: Covid lockdown a year on: 'My dad became my best friend'
item.description: Shireen admits she "didn't really care" about her dad, until lockdown brought them closer than ever.

item.title: Lions at Denver Zoo frolic in the snow after historic blizzard
item.description: These cats enjoyed the record snowfall that hit Colorado over the weekend.

item.title: The Gruffalo: Scent kit brings story to life for visually impaired
item.description: Cupcakes, grass and musty farmyard smells represent characters in the children’s story The Gruffalo.

item.title: 'I don't really know the people I star with'
item.description: Thirteen-year-old Jordan Nash has shared screen time with Hollywood superstars Will Smith and Angelina Jolie.

item.title: Theatres 'ready to fight' after year 'from hell'
item.description: One year since UK theatres shut, industry figures discuss the dire financial impact and reopening plans.

item.title: France to return Klimt painting sold under duress during Nazi era
item.description: A Jewish family was forced to sell Rosiers sous les Arbres after the Nazis annexed Austria in 1938.

item.title: South Korean artist highlights gay rights in military
item.description: Artist and activist Jeram Kang says he was sexually harassed while serving in the South Korean military.

item.title: Why are flowers getting more expensive?
item.description: Increased demand, Brexit costs and Covid-related supply issues have all pushed the price of flowers up.

item.title: Australia March 4 Justice: Thousands march against sexual assault
item.description: Tens of thousands of people across Australia protested against abuse and harassment.

item.title: Cheltenham Festival: 'I gambled £50,000 on a horse and lost everything'
item.description: A former teacher and cricketer is talking about his gambling addiction to help warn others.

item.title: The coffee start-ups brewing up a storm in lockdown
item.description: The pandemic has hit coffee shop chains hard, but some smaller businesses are thriving.

item.title: Festivals 2021: Which ones are still going ahead?
item.description: Glastonbury has had to cancel, Reading & Leeds is going ahead. What about the rest?

item.title: US-China relations: Beyond the 'Cold War' cliche
item.description: A look at the tensions between the superpowers as delegates gather for a meeting in Alaska.

item.title: LGBT rights: New threat for Poland's 'rainbow families'
item.description: A new law aims to close a loophole that is the only remaining way for LGBT people to adopt children.

item.title: Integrated Review: Fact-checking claims about the Army, aid and nuclear weapons
item.description: MPs debating the government's defence review made claims on army funding, international aid and nuclear weapons.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Bitcoin: Fake Elon Musk giveaway scam 'cost man £400,000'
item.description: A German man lost 10 Bitcoin to so-called giveaway scammers on Twitter and experts say scams are rising.

item.title: Zack Snyder's Justice League: A 'vindication' of director's vision, say critics
item.description: The director's reworked cut arrives on Thursday - and most say it's an improvement on the original.

item.title: So you want a career in building computer games?
item.description: A career in computer games can be rewarding but tough to get into.

item.title: Covid lockdown: Charities warn cancer death rate could rise
item.description: Nearly 50 cancer charities send a stark warning about the impact Covid-19 has had on UK cancer care.

item.title: Pickleball: The racquet sport experiencing a pandemic boom
item.description: Pickleball - a mash-up of tennis, badminton and ping-pong - saw a surge in participation last year.

item.title: 'Solidarity and survival': Streamed play has Sheffield songs and steel
item.description: A streamed play marries monologues about "strength" with songs by Sheffield's musical heroes.

item.title: Sarah Everard vigil: 'All I wanted was to stand with other women'
item.description: Why hundreds of women felt compelled to take part in the vigil for Sarah Everard - despite being told it was cancelled.

item.title: Grammys 2021: Five weird and wonderful moments
item.description: Harry Styles, Dua Lipa and Megan Thee Stallion all put on a spectacle. But who are Silk Sonic?

item.title: What is the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill and how will it change protests?
item.description: Public protests have pushed the government's controversial new police bill into the spotlight.

item.title: Everyone’s Invited: Children recount 'rape culture' experiences
item.description: More than 4,000 people have submitted their experiences to an online platform.

item.title: Discovering WW1 tunnel of death hidden in France for a century
item.description: The bodies of 270 German soldiers have lain hidden since they were buried alive by a French bombardment.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Has Covid changed hospitals for the better?
item.description: Dr John Wright of Bradford Royal Infirmary says some changes made as a result of the pandemic are here to stay.

item.title: Review: The Grammy Awards reflect a year of solitude and protest
item.description: Quarantine songs and Black Lives Matter anthems defined this year's music awards.

item.title: We asked for your first Covid text messages. These are your stories
item.description: The US didn’t shut down until late March, but Americans were talking about the virus before that.

item.title: De Bruyne and Gundogan goals see Man City advance comfortably in Champions League
item.description: Manchester City move into the Champions League quarter-finals for a fourth successive season by eliminating Borussia Monchengladbach.

item.title: Impressive Buttler leads England to emphatic T20 win over India
item.description: Jos Buttler's brutal hitting trumps the genius of Virat Kohli in England's eight-wicket defeat of India in the third Twenty20 in Ahmedabad.

item.title: 'If you want to be a jockey, you can be' - Blackmore wants to inspire others after historic win
item.description: Jockey Rachael Blackmore says she hopes her historic triumph might inspire others after winning the Champion Hurdle at Cheltenham on Honeysuckle.

item.title: 'There's still hunger in this team' - Real Madrid march into Champions League last eight
item.description: Goals from Karim Benzema, Sergio Ramos and Marco Asensio ease Real Madrid past Atalanta and into the Champions League quarter-finals.

item.title: Thomas Tuchel: Can Chelsea boss find goals after restoring Blues harmony?
item.description: Thomas Tuchel has restored equilibrium to Chelsea but can he get them scoring?

item.title: Lionel Messi scores twice as he equals Xavi's Barcelona appearance record in 4-1 win
item.description: Watch highlights of Barcelona's 4-1 win over SD Huesca - including two goals from Lionel Messi as he equals Xavi's all-time Barcelona appearance record.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: How many people have had their vaccine in the UK?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 24 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: When will pubs, gyms and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Data by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the test-and-trace system work?
item.description: MPs have said the government's test-and-trace system is too expensive and hasn't helped fight the pandemic.

item.title: Does the Oxford vaccine have a blood clot problem? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: How do we know Covid vaccines are safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: What are the Brazil, South Africa and UK variants and will vaccines work?
item.description: More cases are being found in the UK, including a variant first seen in Brazil.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: What happens if I don't get the Covid vaccine?
item.description: There are multiple coronavirus vaccines being rolled out in countries across the UK and around the world. What happens if you don't want it?

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of new variants of Covid-19.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK. So when might you get one?

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Who truly was the most dishonest president?
item.description: Past US presidents have left a legacy of untruths ranging from the bizarre to the horrifying.
